statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

article.description: Antoine Walker scored a season-high 42 points and the Boston Celtics caught a break when Latrell Sprewell missed a foul shot late in regulation as they beat the New York Knicks 102-93 in overtime Tuesday night.
article.headline: Walker's 42 enough to overcome Spree's 49

images.name: Sprewell_Latrell 121101 inline
images.caption: Latrell Sprewell got to 49, but a missed free throw late allowed the Celtics to go OT and win.

article.linkText: Celtics finally get victory in MSG
article.story:
NEW YORK (AP) -- There doesn't appear to be a big difference between scoring 49 points and scoring 50. For Latrell Sprewell and the New York Knicks, it was the difference between a win and a loss. Antoine Walker scored a season-high 42 points, and Boston caught a break when Sprewell missed a foul shot late in regulation that would have given him 50 as the Celtics beat the New York Knicks 102-93 in overtime Tuesday night. "Coach O'Brien told us at halftime, 'No matter if he scores 50, let's just win the game,' " Walker said. Walker shot 14-for-33 with nine assists and nine rebounds. Paul Pierce added 18 points and six steals, and Kenny Anderson had 14 points and 10 rebounds. Sprewell scored a career-high 49 points and could have reached 50 to give New York a four-point lead and all but lock up the victory with 6.2 seconds left. But with a few people in the crowd yelling, "We want 50," Sprewell missed the first of two free throws to give the Celtics one last chance. "I wasn't so concerned about getting the 50 as I was about making the two," Sprewell said. "It was fun, but it takes the fun away that we didn't win." Walker then got free behind the 3-point arc as he received the inbounds pass, and his shot tied it at 89-89 with 3.6 seconds left. Sprewell took the final shot of regulation, but Pierce got a piece of it and the game went to overtime. "It was a great call by Coach O'Brien. It was a play we hadn't run all year. When I saw myself that open, I just let it go," Walker said. Sprewell, who surpassed his previous career high of 46, was held scoreless in overtime. Allan Houston added 24 for New York, which was playing its second game under Don Chaney following the resignation of Jeff Van Gundy. The Celtics won for the seventh time in eight games and remained ahead of the Knicks in the Atlantic Division. With New York leading 88-86, the Celtics got the ball to Tony Battie for a layup with 10 seconds left, but he missed the shot. Sprewell was fouled with 6.2 seconds left but missed the free throw that would have made him the first Knicks player to score 50 since Patrick Ewing did it Dec. 1, 1990. The Knicks missed their first three shots of the extra period and allowed the Celtics to quickly open a five-point lead. Walker came up with a steal and fed Pierce for an alley-oop dunk with 1:33 left to make it 98-91. A missed shot and a turnover on their next two possessions finished the Knicks' chances. "Since I've been here we've been the doormat for everyone, and it's good to see this team getting turned around," Pierce said. Sprewell's scoring flurry began early in the second quarter when he hit three consecutive shots -- two of them 3-pointers -- in the first 1:11. Sprewell scored 19 points in the quarter, giving him 26 at halftime. Sprewell and Houston combined to score 41 of the Knicks' 47 first-half points. Sprewell reached 30 points on a corner jumper with 7:44 left in the third, then reached 40 with 3:07 left in the third after hitting consecutive 3s. He went into the fourth quarter with 42 points, but didn't score again until making a short shot from the corner with 5:38 left for an 83-80 lead.

Game notes
Van Gundy said on WFAN radio that he has no plans for his future other than attending spring training with his father and learning a few magic tricks. ... The last time a Knicks player other than Patrick Ewing scored 40 points at the Garden was March 9, 1985, when Bernard King had 43 vs. Philadelphia. The last time someone other than Ewing scored 40 anywhere for New York was Gerald Wilkins' 43 at New Jersey on Feb. 21, 1987.
